docs.abstract: The cyclones and floods that hit the world’s most densely populated country nearly every year can’t be stopped. But the warning system now in place is reducing loss and saving lives.
docs.snippet: The cyclones and floods that hit the world’s most densely populated country nearly every year can’t be stopped. But the warning system now in place is reducing loss and saving lives.
docs.lead_paragraph: KHULNA, Bangladesh — In May 2009, Cyclone Aila swept over the southwestern coast of this country and lashed the small village where Rashida Gazi and her husband Rezaul live. The middle-aged couple, who eked out a living from farming and raising livestock in Koyra, knew the cyclone was approaching.

headline.main: In Bangladesh, More Shelter From the Storms

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies

docs.abstract: Abercrombie & Fitch became the second American company to agree to the legally enforceable plan to improve safety standards in Bangladesh.
docs.snippet: Abercrombie & Fitch became the second American company to agree to the legally enforceable plan to improve safety standards in Bangladesh.
docs.lead_paragraph: Abercrombie & Fitch said on Wednesday that it had signed on to a landmark plan to improve factory safety in Bangladesh, becoming just the second American company to join an accord that more than two dozen European retailers and brands have embraced.

headline.main: Abercrombie & Fitch Signs Bangladesh Safety Plan
headline.print_headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Signs Bangladesh Safety Plan

docs.abstract: Westerners horrified by the latest factory disaster would make matters worse by not buying clothing made in Bangladesh. The key to improved worker safety is law enforcement and worker empowerment.
docs.snippet: Westerners horrified by the latest factory disaster would make matters worse by not buying clothing made in Bangladesh. The key to improved worker safety is law enforcement and worker empowerment.
docs.lead_paragraph: BANGLADESH, my country, is again in tears. Last week in Savar, a suburb of Dhaka, the capital, a poorly constructed building that housed garment factories and other businesses collapsed. More than 300 have been confirmed dead, and the final death toll could well exceed 700.

headline.main: Bangladesh Needs Strong Unions, Not Outside Pressure
headline.print_headline: Bangladesh Needs Strong Unions, Not Outside Pressure

docs.abstract: The industry’s trade group has seen its influence soar in recent years, but critics say the group has helped make the nation dangerous for garment workers.
docs.snippet: The industry’s trade group has seen its influence soar in recent years, but critics say the group has helped make the nation dangerous for garment workers.
docs.lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — In the honking, congested heart of this overcrowded capital, one glass office tower stands uniquely alone, surrounded by water, accessible by a small bridge. It is a symbol of the power of Bangladesh’s garment industry, the headquarters of the country’s most powerful association of factory owners. It is also illegal.

headline.main: Garment Trade Wields Power in Bangladesh
headline.print_headline: Garment Trade Wields Power In Bangladesh

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers and Exporters Assn

docs.abstract: In Bangladesh, where floods regularly disrupt education, a nonprofit group has found a way of using wooden boats to deliver classes and books to rural communities.
docs.snippet: In Bangladesh, where floods regularly disrupt education, a nonprofit group has found a way of using wooden boats to deliver classes and books to rural communities.
docs.lead_paragraph: NASIAR KANDI, Bangladesh — On a hot morning, about 20 fourth-graders sat in two rows of desks, their textbooks open to a Bengali poem called “Song of Palki.” One student wrote on the blackboard in the low-roofed room with whitewashed bamboo walls.

headline.main: ‘Floating Schools’ Bring Classrooms to Stranded Students
headline.print_headline: 'Floating Schools' Bring Classrooms to Stranded Students

docs.abstract: A woman named Reshma was found gasping but alive in the wreckage of a garment building, and the reaction in Bangladesh was euphoric.
docs.snippet: A woman named Reshma was found gasping but alive in the wreckage of a garment building, and the reaction in Bangladesh was euphoric.
docs.lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Day after day, the grim drudgery of digging for bodies had progressed at Rana Plaza. Talk of rescuing survivors had faded. This was the recovery phase, and what was being recovered were corpses, the numbers spinning remorselessly forward: 700 dead became 800, then 900, with no end in sight.

headline.main: 17 Days in Darkness, a Cry of ‘Save Me,’ and Joy
headline.print_headline: 17 Days in Darkness, a Cry of ‘Save Me,’ and Joy

byline.original: By Julfikar Ali Manik and Jim Yardley

docs.abstract: Assam may be emblematic of the kind of catastrophe soon to hit much of developing Asia.
docs.snippet: Assam may be emblematic of the kind of catastrophe soon to hit much of developing Asia.

headline.main: Climate Change and Population Growth Meet Along the Brahmaputra River

docs.abstract: After their reluctance to join an earlier alliance, Wal-Mart, Gap and others are joining another plan for Bangladesh led by a nonprofit group in Washington.
docs.snippet: After their reluctance to join an earlier alliance, Wal-Mart, Gap and others are joining another plan for Bangladesh led by a nonprofit group in Washington.
docs.lead_paragraph: Feeling pressure from consumer and labor groups for not doing more to ensure factory safety in Bangladesh, Wal-Mart, Gap and numerous other retailers along with the nation’s main retail federations are seeking to forge a new plan to promote safety in that country’s apparel industry.

headline.main: U.S. Retailers Announce New Factory Safety Plan
headline.print_headline: U.S. Retailers Announce New Factory Safety Plan

docs.abstract: A genealogy of textile factory disasters.
docs.snippet: A genealogy of textile factory disasters.

docs.abstract: Health workers implementing family planning programs in the northeastern state of Assam struggle against religious traditions, illiteracy, and poverty.
docs.snippet: Health workers implementing family planning programs in the northeastern state of Assam struggle against religious traditions, illiteracy, and poverty.
docs.lead_paragraph: MAZERCHAR CHALAKURA, Assam — On the banks of the Brahmaputra River, off the coast of Dhubri town in the northeastern state of Assam, lie a few hundred villages that seem stuck in time, difficult to reach from the mainland and undeveloped for decades.

headline.main: On Assam’s River Islands, Family Planning Clashes Against Religious Tradition
